Travelblogue I was going to write about my trip to Missouri in detail, but I have decided just to post some observations. It's going to be boring either way, but this way it is shorter. We took I-40 until we reached Oklahoma, where we took various turnpikes. I took my digital camera along and attempted to take photos. This was not easy, as my camera isn't very good at "action" shots because it takes a while to take the photo. I had to try to anticipate when I would be in the right place before I hit the shutter. My judgement of the delay of the camera wasn't always good, as the photo of the front end of a BNSF train (See below) demonstrates. Welcome to "Fort Tourist Trap" On the way to our first stop in Santa Rosa NM, I got to see a stretch of I-40 that I had seen many times while I was in college at UNM. It's boring as hell between Flagstaff and Albuquerque. There are all sorts of strange attractions along this road like dinosaurs and various "Indian" trading posts (see the photos below). These shops usually feature a mishmash of Anglo stereotypes about Native Americans such as tepees with dancing Kachinas painted on them. Further down the road they even have billboards with "Running Indian" on it: a comic figure of a little Indian man in a headdress and tomahawk running in his moccasins. The irony is that real Native Americans live in these places, and one wonders what they think of the images of them presented by these roadside attractions. (In fact, some of them may be Native American-owned). Just down the road from the wooden tepees sits a traditional Navajo hogan (see photo below) with its many sides and door facing east. If you look closely as you pass through this area you can see many hogans of all sizes and made from any kind of material from logs to cinder block. Complimentary Scorpion In Santa Rosa we ate at a place called the Lake City Diner (see photo) on 4th street. If you even go though Santa Rosa and can take a break, you have to visit it. The food is excellent. I had a green chile chicken enchilada because when you're in New Mexico you must have the green chiles. The diner is located in the First National Bank building constructed in 1901, and the waiter station is located in the old vault. After dinner we saw another one of Santa Rosa's attractions, The Blue Hole (see photo). This is a spring that is 81 feet deep and very clear. People use it for scuba diving and swimming. Our stay in Santa Rosa would have been better if we had not found a scorpion in our room after we returned from seeing the Blue Hole! There was a large crack under our door, and I think it may have crawled in that way. (I don't have a photo of it because we were trying to kill it.) No one slept well that night, and when we told the lady in the office the next morning her response was: "Oh yeah. They come out after we spray and we just sprayed." We told her about the gap under the door and she said "Oh yeah, I'll tell the maintenance guy." I got the impression that she wouldn't. Texas I noticed an abandoned railway alignment that follows Route 66. All that remains is a berm with ties (sleepers?) set on top of it. I have a photo posted of the pilings of a small bridge (see below). I could see this alignment from eastern NM, across Texas and into OK. I think I saw an old station some miles outside of Amarillo, Texas. In this area the track bed was nothing more that a slight linear disturbance in the ground that can be seen from I-40. I am in the process of trying to figure out what it is, but I think it might be an abandoned route of the Chicago, Rock Island, and Gulf railway, but I am waiting on confirmation of this. If so, the rails along this route were taken up in 1984. We also passed the urlLink "Big Texan" where they have this HUGE steak, like 72 oz. If you can eat it in an hour it's free. (I believe this was parodied on an episode of the Simpson‚Äôs). Unfortunately, I wasn‚Äôt able to get a photo of the restaurant. You can‚Äôt miss it. It‚Äôs a huge yellow complex of buildings. Another roadside attraction is the Leaning Water tower outside of Groom, Texas (see photo). According to this urlLink website The tower, which says ‚ÄúBRITTEN USA‚Äù is actually part of a Route 66 truck stop. The Britten truck stop put up the leaning tower to attract business, and it still attracts many photos. (Just Google ‚ÄúBRITTEN USA‚Äù and see what you get!) The Britten tower is very near the ‚ÄúLargest Cross in the Western Hemisphere‚Äù (see photo). In fact, there is a curve in the westbound lane of I-40 where they can be seen on the horizon together. (No photo, unfortunately) We stopped at what must be the last gas station with a full-service pump in the US. It was a 1970‚Äôs (?) era Chevron station near Amarillo. I had not heard the sound of a gas station bell since I was a small child living in Missouri. I took a photo of a tile I found in the ladies room. It was a typical dirty gas station restroom (but not the worst I have ever seen). Always on the lookout for irony, I snapped this photo (see below) of a tile describing that the bathroom is checked regularly (once a year?) etc.... I also saw a sight that can only be seen in Texas: A large propane tank with a Texas flag flying from it. (D*mn, no picture!) We soon said goodbye to Texas and hello to Oklahoma. We passed through Yukon, OK, apparently the home of Garth Brooks. I have a photo of the water tower bearing this information below. My great-aunt lives in OK City, but we didn't have time to visit her. In Oklahoma the countryside finally started to look more mid-western as we got on one of the many turnpikes. The motel in Joplin, MO was scorpion-free. The only odd things we saw in OK was a man with a telephoto lens taking pictures of an overpass on one of the turnpikes. Bombs Bursting in Air The next day we made it to my grandparents‚Äô house in Missouri, near the Lake of the Ozarks. The road to their house is a winding two-lane highway lined with small mom and pop shops, antique stores, boat lift shops, small car dealerships, lumber yards, barber shops, garages, and little restaurants that have Friday fish-fries. It was such a relief to see a landscape that was not scraped off and paved over with identical strip malls and soulless housing developments like I saw in AZ, NM, TX and even OK. Not a chain store or restaurant could be found, expect the occasional Pizza Hut. Anyone on the hunt for a Frappucchino would be sorely disappointed. Dotted among these shops were numerous yellow and orange striped tents filled with fireworks. I have never purchased or had a chance to set any off before (since they are illegal here), so we bought some sparklers and snakes (see photo below). I was astounded at some of the fireworks that were sold at these stands. They ranged from innocent bottle-rockets and firecrackers to huge shells with big cardboard tubes from which to launch them. The big fireworks had names like "The Heart Stopper," "Mystical Dragon," and "Do You Hear What I'm Sayin'?" This is the same nation where we have to put ‚ÄúCaution: Contents Hot‚Äù on coffee cups to avoid lawsuits, so I find it amazing that we let people play with explosives without training or a license of any kind. I noticed that the fireworks are made in China from a company in Hong Kong, so I doubt they have any liability and you would never be able to sue them if you wanted to. Antique Stores There are many antique stores in this part of Missouri as well. I like to go to antique stores in Missouri because they tend to have actual antiques. In Arizona antique stores tend to carry junk from the 1970's. I purchased what might be a 1900-1918 Ernst Wahliss art pottery (porcelain) vase. It's not very big or fancy, but I only paid $12 for it (see photo above). The woman who owned the little store said that people demand a very cheap price for her wares and then turn around and sell them on ebay. Soon it was time to go home, and all I can say about the return trip was that it was all of the above in reverse, minus the scorpion. (Not really, but I think this blog is long enough already) We did see the Jacket Fire that is burning near Flagstaff. It wasn‚Äôt much of anything at the time, but now it threatens to burn a major powerline that feeds Phoenix.

Oscar Night I was watching bits of the Oscars tonight and I was sickened by Michael Mooreís fictitious acceptance speech. I have nothing against people speaking out, but the Oscars is not the appropriate forum. My war Blog: (Part 1) AKA: Some opinions of the uninformed: To be honest I donít know what I think about this war. I guess that is why I am not too upset about the demonstrators on either side of this thing. At the outset I was convinced that president Bush had some kind of intelligence that suggested that Saddam Hussein was a threat. There had to be a reason for him to be pounding the war drum beyond the well-known personal grudge. I supported the war at that point. As the months went on, there was no evidence of anything that might make Saddam an immediate threat. I still hoped we had secret and damning intelligence that we could not share for some reason. Bush went to the UN, which I thought was a good idea. No weapons were found, but the Iraqis did a great job of stalling, giving the UN bullshit documents, and hiding things from the inspectors. They didnít allow U2 spy planes to be used (Which should not be a problem if he has nothing to hide.) Saddam is a ruthless, evil man with a history of lying and noncompliance. However, if we were watching him, wasnít that a form of containment? What could he do while we were watching him and inspectors were crawling all over Iraq? Why couldnít we wait? On the other hand, he had 12 years to comply, and I doubt he had any intention of doing so. President Bush castigates the UN for being impotent. This is nothing new; for as long as I can remember the UN has done a lot of talking and has rarely taken action. They put peacekeepers in a war-torn country but refuse to let them fire their weapons to keep the peace, they talk about punishing rogue states but refuse to put armies together to do it. Bush was right to compare them to the League of Nations. However, our government pushed and pushed, like a spoiled child to get their wishes passed, and when France, Germany, and Russia refused, we threw a temper tantrum. Of course Russia and France were selling arms to the Iraqis, a violation of their own precious UN treaty. (The French owe us one, by the way.) The US, Britain, and Australia go ahead with war anyway. A Coalition of three. Tony Blair. This guy has guts. I have to respect him for going against his party and his people to support us. He was immensely supportive after September 11th and continues to be despite the political pressure against him. I have to wonder what Bush said to him, or what intelligence he shared with Blair to convince him. Tony Blair has been compared to Bill Clinton, but Clinton would never have had the courage to do something unpopular, even if he felt it was right. To be continuedÖ.

My War Blog Part 2 AKA: Some Opinions of the Marginally Informed I have been busy lately, so I havenít added to this thing as often as I would like to. I had the intention of writing some long-winded essay on how I feel about this war. I think thatís unnecessary since I seem to change my mind daily. Bottom line: If Iraq is truly dangerous to our national security (for reasons that are still secret or I assume they would have shared them with us), then I support this war. If this is an excuse by President Bush to go after Saddam for personal reasons, then I will not be voting for him in the next presidential election. (Hell, I may not vote for him anyway.) Iím not sure any of us, as in regular civvies will really know what is going on until itís all over. I find it interesting that Bush was itching to attack Iraq right after 9/11 BEFORE going after Al Qaeda. Thank goodness Tony Blair talked him out of it. I donít understand the logic of going after a potentially dangerous state while ignoring the one that actually carried out the attack. My friends were all opposed to the war in Afghanistan, but I wasnít. It was necessary and justified, and I hope the Second Gulf War is as well. The Media and the War I read a page on the Beebís website (http://www.BBC.com/ ) about public opinion on media coverage of the War. People from all over the world could post their opinions. I find it interesting that two people could watch the same coverage and one could declare it pinko-liberal and pro-Iraqi, and another sees it as a jingoistic propaganda tool of the US Government. I guess it all depends on which side of center you happen to lean. Since I donít quite know which way I lean (despite the party affiliation on my voter registration card), I see most of the major networks as being anti-war before the war broke out, and still so, but in a subtle way. The reporters make snide remarks every so often about the progress of the war or the performance of the troops, yet there are few reports about civilian losses (Except from Arab TV, which is a propaganda mill as well). I get the feeling that weíre getting a sanitized version of events, but the reporters arenít really happy about it. The BBC World Service, once the bastion of balanced reporting, is broadcasting nonstop negative reports about what the US is doing in Iraq. They seem to forget that there are British soldiers involved as well (It must have slipped their mind). Their website seems to be much better, with a mixture of good and bad news. I just try to remember that itís all propaganda in some form or another. Opinion I want to hear news, not opinion. Peter Arnet is in trouble for giving his opinion. He can have an opinion, but itís not his job to report it. Get an editorial column if you feel like voicing you opinions, otherwise just stick to the facts (Or a close approximation). This just in: Now weíre making noises about going after Syria. I hope this is not true. Random thought: Whatís wrong with a little jingoism now and then?

A Usenet Community I have been lurking and posting to Usenet since 1996 when I was liberated from AOL. Lately, I have been thinking about the sociology of online communities. I actually had a Soc. professor who had done her dissertation on Usenet. My favourite newsgroup has always been alt.fan.letterman (AFL). I first posted a message there sometime in 1996. Over the years there have been personalities who have drifted in and out of the newsgroup (NG). One pillar of AFL is Don Giller (AKA Donz, Donz5), who is the foundation of the NG. I started reading Donzís Letterman Folder posts when I was on AOL in 1993. He has taped and compiled a database of every Late Night and Late Show that was ever broadcast. Ask Donz any LN/LS-related question and he can answer it. For example, one could ask who was on the show on Feb 13, 1983, and if there was a show on that night, he could tell you who the guests were and even what bits were done. His archive has been so valuable that the producers of a Headliners and Legends special on David Letterman tapped Donzís personal goldmine for material. Two other AFLíers (Traci and Carl) also contributed to the special. AFL is a tight-knit little online community of posters and goodness knows how many lurkers. Even staffers from the Late Show have been known to lurk and post. However, Dave does not read AFL as far as we know, and posts addressed to him will be answered with a sarcastic ìDave ainít here, man.î Each night the show is summarised and dissected. Guests are torn to shreds for being boring, flighty, or stupid, comedy bits are judged for lameness, every piece of music played by the CBSO is carefully logged, and the show as a whole is summed up in a concise Late Show Quick Guide. Two AFL regulars make screen captures of key points in the show and post them on their web sites. There is even a place for fanfic-if you dare. Even the trolls are relatively interesting in AFL. One in particular likes to post ellipsis-filled inane messages usually ending in ìÖ.HOLY CRAP!î Then there is a troll who will teach you the finer points of Gentonism. (No I donít what Gentonism is either). The AFL community extends beyond the Internet. Each summer, selected AFLers converge on 53rd and Broadway to attend ìDaveCon,î the annual pilgrimage of the Dave faithful. They attend a taping or two, and are often allowed to go onstage and even backstage after the show. Each time an AFLer attends a show, they are obligated to prepare an online ìTrip Reportî with photos describing their experience. And AFL has even changed lives. AFLíers Sharon Best and Alan Page met through AFL, and are now engaged to be married. They met at a Late Show taping in October (The Warren Zevon Show). The AFL family keeps the NG alive and bristling with humour, dripping with sarcasm and riddled with AFL-specific acronyms that drive newbies insane. For example: NTTAWTT, SLDSH, AITWAKHPTCB, etc. If you are interested in posting to this NG, mind you lurk before you leap. There are many in-jokes and running gags that create a minefield for the uninitiated. Such subjects as pie, honeymoons, and dental floss have special significance and should not be taken lightly. A good command of English grammar and spelling are a must. AFL is a great companion to the Late Show, and my viewing experience isnít complete until I have read it. Oh, and whatever you do, donít ever mention Harry Truman. Youíll thank me later. AFLer Sofia Norberg once posted this about the dynamic in AFL: "To make posting here at Ass-Bitch Central more enjoyable for everyone, every post is now scrutinized by grammar goons and spelling nazis, torn apart by smart-asses and cranky bastards, then graded 'funny' or 'not' by a guy who thinks I'm a newbie, after which more hilarity ensues as the Inner Sanctum argue among themselves about whether his choices are right or wrong, and then - finally - we all view the scoreboard so we can tell who's funnier." Netscape R.I.P. I read on Auntie Beeb (The BBC online) the other day that Netscape is being discontinued. I was a bit sad to hear this, as I have been using Netscape since 1995. This article contained some links to other sites, including mozilla.org, and a site that offers browser emulators for a walk down memory lane. The site lets you chose a dinosaur browser and one of their links or put in your own and see how the old browsers performed. I chose Netscape Navigator c. 1994. I went to some familiar pages and saw how there were no background images, no frames, no tables, no Java. Just a long page of text and pictures that one would have to scroll through. Ah, the good old days. I sometimes forget that it has almost been a decade since I first surfed the Web. I joined AOL in 1993, and knew about the Web, but as I said we didn’t have access to it at first. I remember waiting impatiently for the new service. I can’t imagine living without it. I didn’t get to experience the Web until 1994 (?), when AOL made it available to it’s users with a terrible clunky piece-of-crap browser that was primitive even for that time. I left AOL in 1995 for a real ISP, and was able to use Netscape (Netscape was much faster and more stable.) and having been using some version of it ever since. Upon hearing the news that Netscape was doomed, I downloaded the latest version of Mozilla. I will give it a test drive tonight to see how it shapes up. It is similar in appearance and layout to Netscape for obvious reasons, but I don’t yet know how it handles. It does seem to have some additional and useful features. The BBS This has made me nostalgic! I remember when we got our first PC, a 286 15 MHz IBM clone, built for us by a guy we knew who ran a small local computer company. It was quite a mysterious thing, especially to someone like me who had only used Apples and the odd TRS 80 (A dinosaur even at that time!). It had a color VGA screen, and a mouse. It had a 40 MB internal hard drive (The guy claimed it was all we would ever need). Most importantly it had a modem. The guy who built the computer left a list of phone numbers to call. These were Bulletin Board Systems (BBS) around town. It took me a while to get up the courage to dial one up on our screaming 2600 baud modem, but I finally did. Before long I was listed on several local BBS’ and became acquainted with some of the sysops, none of whom I ever met face to face. There was one in particular, a guy who’s handle was “Nifty Corpse,” who seemed to be quite famous in the local BBS community. One time a sysop broke in and we chatted. He said it was rare that girls would join a BBS, and of course he tried to pick me up (he would not have bothered if he could have seen me). The sysop tried to impress me with his computer. It was a kick ass something that he had built himself with all the newest, fastest guts and software. It was impressive, but then he ruined the moment by mentioning that he drove a VW Rabbit. I suppose one must have priorities. I soon became interested in ANSI graphics (remember that!?) and downloaded a little program called “The Draw” that allowed one to produce these lovely images. The best part about the whole BBS thing was ITCNet and FidoNet. I used to read the ITCNet teen chat. It was exciting to read messages posted by people all over the US! (Remember this was before I had AOL). It was my first taste of something like Usenet. I also found the “Berlin Connection” a BBS that specialised in connecting Americans with family and friends serving in Germany. My friend Sara introduced me to AOL when we were in High School, and I never went back to the BBS. I wonder if any of them are still around? They were really the equivalent of a home page now. Each one was designed by the author (sysop) just as they wanted it, with their own ANSI art and with discussion boards devoted to their interests. To me, AOL was a much flashier and bigger version of a BBS, and I found it very impressive at the time. Later I found AOL cumbersome and irritating. Why I left AOHell To be honest I left AOL for a bunch of reasons, mostly that AOL simply didn’t work (This was early 1995 and they were growing so fast that their infrastructure could not keep up. I assume it has improved or they would have gone out of business). I also became annoyed with their online tech support. Tech support was set up as a chat room, and you would go in and wait in a virtual queue for the tech to get to your question. I have noticed that President Bushís case for war in Iraq closely paralleled the efforts of Winston Churchill to alert the world to the threat posed by Hitler. It makes one wonder if President Bush and PM Tony Blair have read ìThe Gathering Stormî and used it as a guide. President Bush did make reference to appeasing dictators and the League of Nations. The obvious difference is that Hitler was a very grave threat, but the full scale Saddamís threat to our country, if any, has yet to be proven. Last night I was reading a chapter in ìTheir Finest Hourî and it contained my favourite Churchill quote: ëHistory with its flickering lamp stumbles along the trail of the past trying to reconstruct its scenes, to revive its echoes, and kindle with pale gleams the passion of former days.í Churchill said those words about his late predecessor Neville Chamberlain. I expect I am missing his true meaning, but Churchill goes on to question the use of history with its flawed and incomplete view of the past. He argues that a man is really measured by his conscience. Churchill knew Chamberlain would be judged harshly, so he chose to highlight his intentions, not his foibles. Chamberlain wanted to avoid another bloody, pointless war, and he only failed in his attempt because he was signing a worthless pact with an evil and duplicitous man. Churchill argued that when hearts are weighed, the flawed picture presented by history loses its importance. Why am I going on about this? I think this principle may apply to Prime Minister Tony Blair and President George W. Bush today. With what intention and with what conscience did these men make the heavy decision to go to war? Was it for the good of Iraq and for our two nations, or was it for some other, less noble purpose? Were the data on WMD embellished, and if so, why? If the real reason for war was not WMD, then why not reveal the truth to us? Surely if it was compelling enough for President Bush and Prime Minister Blair, it would be so for the rest of the world.

The following is only my opinion as an American who is watching this unfold on TV and reading it on the BBC online. 11-M Today a terrorist group has influenced the elections in a free democratic nation. The significance of this event cannot be underestimated. Last Thursday, March 11, 2004 terrorists murdered 201 people and injured 1,400 others. For the Spanish, 11 March will always be a day of mourning just as 11 September is for us. This attack came on the eve of important national elections. The day before the attack the election was almost too close to call but after it was revealed that al-Qaeda, not Eta, might have been responsible for the attack, there was a change in public opinion. It was as if the people of Spain saw the attacks as a result of the ruling party's support of the war in Iraq and they cast their votes accordingly. A large majority of the Spanish people did not support the decision to help the United States in the war in Iraq, so one might argue that the attack drove more people to go out and vote. Isn't this a textbook example of democracy in action? It would seem to be at first glance, but upon closer inspection something more insidious is revealed. To this American observer it looked as if the Spanish believed that they could bargain for their security by voting for a government that would pull Spanish troops out of Iraq. This was not democracy in action; it was the manipulation of an election by fear and the slaughter of innocent people. If the election results were just a coincidence, a sort of collateral effect of the attack, then it was far more successful than the terrorists ever intended. Several European nations seem to be returning to the idea that they will be safe as long as they try not to do anything that might give their enemies a reason to attack them. This did not work in the past (e.g. the appeasement policies of the 1930's) and it will not work now. The French are worried about an attack in retaliation for legislation to ban religious symbols such as headscarves in state schools. In this case it is not their involvement with the US that makes France a possible target, but their own internal policy. What is to stop the terrorists from carrying out attacks wherever and whenever they please because they disagree with national policy? Are the Europeans going to have to think twice every time they pass a law? Today the terrorists have won. They have learned that they can use bombs not only to kill but also to influence the outcome of a democratic election. If we allow this to continue we are giving up our freedom and opening the door to a threat that is every bit as perilous as that posed by communism, fascism, or any other oppressive ideology that is spread and maintained by terror, coercion, and mass murder.

I was eager to show him that I could work independently. After all, he had told me that this was the kind of employee he was looking for. I tried to get things done before he even asked for them. I never let him down, I always did what he asked, and he never complained about the quality of my work. However, things did not get better. Whenever I sent a fax he just could not believe I managed to send it without jamming. He sat right next to me at my desk when he dictated letters and e-mails. Sometimes I didn't even have enough room on my desk to type. If he didn't like the way I was doing something he would take the mouse out of my hand and do it for me (even if I knew how to do it). It was very frustrating. He would also insist that I write down everything he said, and he wouldn't give me directions until I had pen and paper. If you use Microsoft Office, then you know that there is usually about three ways you can carry out any command such as writing a formula in Excel or setting margins in Word. He would insist I did it his way, which was usually not the way I knew how to do it. I had no choice because he sat right next to me when I worked, and he would scold me and tell me I was wrong if I tried to do it differently. I tried to do things his way if it was faster or more efficient than the way I did it. I finally decided that I needed to talk to him. I told him that it made me very nervous when he sat next to me when I worked. His response (paraphrasing here): "I know it makes you nervous, but it doesn't bother me that it makes you nervous and frustrated." Then he went on to say: "There is more than one way to do something." Right! This was exactly the point I was trying to make. However, it soon became apparent that there was more than one way as long as it was his way. So having been defeated on that point, I decided to bring up my second concern. I told him that I didn't feel like he trusted me to do my job and I didn't know why. His response: "Because I don't think you know how to do it." It would have been better if he had said I was ugly and I smelled bad. I knew exactly what I was doing, but because I didn't do it his way, he had assumed I didn't know how to do it at all. I gave my notice. He tried to talk me into staying, and then he went off about how he had 8 years of college and how he went to grad school (I never told him I have an MA). He told me he learned such and such about software in college. So I pointed out to him that I knew how to write formulas in Excel because I had used it in stats in school. His response: "Doesn't count! Doesn't count in the real world!" Ok, so let me get this straight: Your college experience counts, but mine doesn't? That makes sense. He also went on to tell me that I could learn valuable "people skills" from him because he's so good with people (I sh*t you not). I take pride in working hard and doing a good job. I don't need to be told I'm doing a good job, but I refuse to work for someone with such a low opinion of my abilities and intelligence (unless it's a job that I really want to keep). Especially since I know damn well how to it. Sometimes you just have to suck it up, but not for this particular job. He actually made me feel worse about myself than I did when I was unemployed. I went in the next morning and left my keys and a note. I was going to leave him this: "After thinking about our conversation yesterday I have decided that I cannot work for __________ anymore. Since I am obviously so incompetent, I am sure that my departure will be of no inconvenience to you." But I decided to take the high road and leave a simple note. I hated doing this, and I don't ever want to do it again. I just want to find a job and stay. The last job I quit was 8 years ago at a fast food joint. I had been there 7 months, which is practically a lifetime in fast food. I hate instability, and I really just want to get a job and stay there so that I can buy a car, move out, etc...

Tech Support Saga My dad bought a D*ll computer this last January for Christmas. We have owned a D*ll before (a 486). It was a good computer and we had no complaints with the tech support. So when he went to buy our newest computer, he decided that the machine he wanted was a D*ll.(We have owned a G*t*w*y and two C*mp*qs too) We ordered it and it arrived very quickly, and all in one piece despite a warning that parts may arrive separately. Then we got an UNMOUNTABLE_BOOT_VOLUME error. I got it working simply by turning it off and letting it sit. This advice was obtained by Goggling the error message. It was the least invasive of methods suggested to repair the problem, including a confusing article on a version of this error code posted on Microsoft's site. Then we got a string of IDE and SATA drive failure messages on bootup (We don't have a SATA drive). It was like the BIOS settings kept changing. I called D*ll's tech support and of course they blamed the error on us, and gave suggestions on how to fix it. I'll spare you the details, but since march I have had to call D*ll once or twice a month for hard drive-related errors. At one point I was even instructed to open the case and unplug the drive to clear the static from it (or so they said). The tech promised us this would solve the problem and that if it happened again they would replace our hard drive. No matter what the problem is the techs invariably blame it on a phantom corrupted file, new software/hardware (in spite of the fact that none was installed), or "power surges". I find this interesting because we have two other computers in the house and none of them have had any of these "very common" problems. We were pretty tired of these bootup errors by the time we received another UNMOUNTABLE_BOOT_VOLUME error this last weekend. I spent the evening on the phone with a tech who was giving me bullshit about how I probably messed up Windows XP by opening a corrupted email (it's the phantom corrupted file again!). We know better than to open emails with files attached to them. I asked him if he could see the history of calls for this system and pointed out to him that the common denominator in all of the problems was the hard drive (or the HD controller?). I also pointed out that I have an H*wl*tt P*ck*rd with XP and I have never had a problem like this with it. This didn't seem to make any sort of impression however, and he made me use the Windows XP disk to run Chkdsk on the hard drive, which he claimed was to fix the phantom file that I had so carelessly corrupted by opening an email. He assured me that he would call me in an hour after the chkdsk was done running and that the computer would reboot. 2 hours later and no call from D*ll support, chkdsk had quit 25% of the way through due to errors, and the system still refused to reboot. Out of desperation I tried restarting it, pressing F12 at the D*ll screen where I had seen a place where you can run a diagnostic on the hard drive. When I did so it said it had failed, and I got a "code 7" or something like that. I had no idea what this meant, but I called D*ll back. The woman told me to do exactly what I had just done (F12, IDE check) and I told her I had got a 7. "Oooh." She says. "Your hard drive has failed." Really?! Might we have a bad hard drive? I would never have guessed it after four months of sporadic HD errors!! So my dad gets on the line with this woman and she tells him how they are going to do the HD replacement. She gave him a phone number for the company that sends out techs to do the work, and a case number. She assured us they would call on Monday to schedule an appointment. Monday comes and no call. I call the phone number the D*ll tech support woman gave me and I get a "This number has been disconnected" message. I call D*ll customer support to complain. She gives me another number to call. I call it and get a woman with a very bad attitude who tells me that their network is down so they can't tell me anything. So that's where we are.

I have just been watching the funeral for President Reagan. I was moved by Nancy Reaganís goodbye to her husband. I felt very strange watching it all. It felt so private and personal. I don't remember anything specific about President Reagan. The first national election that I can remember was for his second term. I was eight at the time. I remember that I wanted him to win. But I never understood what impact he had in the fight against Communism. I knew we were supposed to hate the Soviets and that they could kill us all in a moment if they wanted. I also knew that we would do the same to them. I was not as frightened as I should have been. I remember hearing about Star Wars and how I wanted to believe that we really had such a thing. I just could not believe that anyone could destroy America. My best friend's brother used to try to scare us by telling us that the Soviets had a bunch of missiles aimed right at our city because we had an Air Force base (two, actually). I remember him describing what would happen if we were bombed; he told us that all the lights would go out because the bomb would suck up all of the electricity. Several years later we read "Z for Zechariah" in class. By then I was old enough to have some idea of how much danger we were really in. The following year the Berlin Wall fell. I wasn't paying much attention to world events so I didn't think about President Reagan when the Wall fell, but I had been following some of the changes in the Soviet Union. I saw that there was hope in Gorbachev's reforms. I was aware that the Soviet grip on power was loosening, but I didn't really know why. I have only recently learned about the role that President Reagan played in lifting the Iron Curtain from Eastern Europe and the years of peace and prosperity that followed.

The Second Worst Interview Ever My adventures in interviewing are a regular part of the Bitter Boat, and here is my latest: I have very little experience interviewing. My very first interview wasn't good. It was at a small local bookstore. I think I was in High School or fresh out of school at the time. The man asked me if I had a customer at the front desk and one on the phone what do I do? I replied that you put the one on hold and help the costumer up front. Wrong. He was not at all kind about it either, and basically said I'd ruin him if he let me work for him. My second "interview" was for a fast food job. Got the job that day. My third job (a temp job) was offered to me sight unseen two weeks after I graduated from college with my BA. I got my fourth job two weeks after I finished the third. I had a great interview and was offered the job right there. My latest temp jobs were similar. I knew someone at one company so she hired me based on that. I have had no luck since then. After several interviews that seemed like they went very well, but produced no results, I decided to check out a bunch of interview guides from the library like "Interviewing for Dummies," "How not to look like a total and Complete Idiot at Your Interview,î etc... I read them all and took the advice. Be positive always. Answer every harsh negative question with an answer that would make Pollyanna look like Scrooge. Love everyone. Have no major faults, only little small ones. Turn every negative into a positive. I took the advice and practiced it. I studied. I prepared. I went in and was doing fairly well until he said: "Can you do something for me?" Uh oh. This wasn't in the book. "Answer the phone." There was a telephone by my seat. I thought: ìOk, this is weird, but no problem.î I had just spent two months doing the phones at my last job. I picked up the phone and to my astonishment nothing but total gibberish came out of my mouth. It was a string of noises that did not correspond to words in the English language. I put the receiver down and smiled. "Let me try again." I tried to laugh it off and regain my composure. I picked up the receiver and could not, for the life of me, pronounce the name of the company. Again, odd sounds issued from my lips as if I were speaking a mysterious ancient language. I have had to do presentations in front of people before but I practice. I have always feared that freeze-up that happens to some people, but I haven't had this problem in a long time. This is because I PREPARE for hours. I have it down cold before I open my mouth. This is not to say that I am a great speaker, but I can manage fairly well. The phone caught me off guard, even though it was a perfectly reasonable request. That of course was the end of that. He did keep talking to me for about 10 more minutes, talking about benefits, etc. But I knew it was just a waste of our time. Why torture me with a spiel about the great benefits I would have had had I been able to say "This is Blah Blah and Associates how may I help you?"

I have only seen him in The Singing Detective (1986 mini series) where he had a small part as a soldier on a train, and in one of the Prime Suspect series. I had serious doubts about this casting choice solely based on his physical appearance. There is nothing about the way JKR described Lupin in her books that would suggest that David Thewlis looked wrong for the part. Thewlis won me over completely. He WAS Remus Lupin, and though he may not have looked like my idea of the part, he acted it perfectly and I cannot imagine anyone else doing it. For the record, I also liked his 1920ís (?) clothing and his appreciation of swing music, which were not in the book. Gambonís Dumbledore (Michael Gambon was also in The Singing Detective) didnít quite have the twinkle that Richard Harris gave him, but he wasnít given much of a chance to shine. I hope he will have a bigger part in GoF. WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD: I liked how this film focused on the relationships of the characters but it left out some important details that I think would make the film confusing to the uninitiated. Messrs. Moony, Wormtail, Padfoot, and Prongs were never explained or how the Maraudersí map came to be. Harry thinks the person across the lake making the Patronus is his father. I do not think this was explained at all in the film. I liked the film despite these deficiencies. Potterpotheses I have decided that because I have the time, Iíll start adding my crazy Harry Potter hypotheses to this Blog. Millions of fans havenít been able to crack JKRís story yet, so why should I be able to shed any light on anything? I donít expect that I will, but I might as well post my thoughts. I have not read a lot of analysis of the books and my degree is in Anthropology, not Lit so I will probably make a mess of this. SPOILERS ABOUND!!! Sometimes a moon is just a moon. Remus Lupinís boggart is usually described as a ìsilvery white orb.î The students in his DADA (Defence against the Dark Arts) class think itís a crystal ball when they see it during their boggart lesson. He is also described as fleeing from Professor Trelawney when she tried to give him a reading on her crystal ball. After reading PoA I had thought that JKR used this vague description of his boggart to make sure that it wasnít obvious early on that he was a werewolf, and the boggart was not a crystal ball, but a full moon. However, there is some possibility that the silvery orb may not be a moon. This occurred to me as I re-read the books recently, and it was also suggested by someone in one of the forums. Is the orb a moon, or is it in fact a crystal ball or a globe like those housed in the Department of Mysteries (DoM)? Did he flee from Trelawney because sheís a weird old bat or because he had a fear of what he might see in her crystal ball? If this is the case, here are two possibilities: 1. IIRC, only part of the staff (Snape, and Dumbledore) knew he was a werewolf, so perhaps he feared Trelawney would out him. (To me this is the most likely.) 2. There is something he fears in his future, perhaps a prophesy like the one about LV. I still think itís a just a moon, especially since the boggart in the film is obviously a moon. But itís still fun to speculate. Speaking of moons, JKRís official site is covered in crescent moons. Some say this is a reference to the eventual demise of Remus Lupin. I would like to think that it means that our dear Remus is the Half Blood Prince, however, it could just as easily refer to LUNA Lovegood.

Shipping ñ Potter Style I can recall as if it were yesterday Öyes the X-Files ìfolderî on AOL a decade ago. I have to admit I was a Mulder/Scully ìshipper.î This was my introduction to fan ìshippingî (the act of wanting certain characters to become romantically involved). There were also Scully/Skinner, Scully/Frohike, Scully/Smoking Man even Skinner/Mulder ìshippersî out there on AOL all waiting with bated breath for the moment when their two favorite characters would succumb to their secret smoldering desires on screen. If this did not happen, or if it were happening with the wrong person, these shippers produced copious amounts of fan fiction describing the torrid trysts of their chosen ship. I had all but forgotten about shipping until I started reading several Harry Potter forums. You have not seen shipping until you have sailed the HMS Harry Potter. One board has a ìLove Threadî which I naively thought had something to do with JKRís overarching theme of love (which I strongly suspect is ìthe power the Dark Lord knows not.î OotP Am ver. p. 841). But no, the Love Thread is located in bloody shark-infested waters where many ships are engaged in a fierce and endless battle. I have not had the courage to venture into this thread, but I have heard stories from those who have (and have lived to tell about it). When shipping comes up in conversation on other threads they can range from the possible: Harry/Hermione and Ron/Hermione, to the ridiculous (and downright creepy) like Luna/Lupin. Why not have Trelawney and Remus steaming up the olí Shrieking Shack? How about Mrs Norris/Crookshanks (a bit slashy, that), Mundungus/McGonagall, Snape brewing up a little love potion for Dolores Umbridge, or Filch/Peeves? Quite a few fans have pointed out that Nymphadora Tonks is the most eligible female character because of her age and therefore is the figurehead of many ships. urlLink Check out this very amusing cartoon about Tonks and her unfortunate shipability. I refuse to be on the crew of any ship. I think that the overall story is more important, and only if the ship were key to it would I jump aboard. Although, to be honest I wouldnít mind seeing Professor Lupin find love- even if it is with poor TonksÖ
